title: The Enhanced Crash Investigation Study (ECIS)
segmentation: The The Accident Research Center is moving into Prato actually, which is just North of Florence, so no doubt I'll see even more of you in the years to come.

Thank you, I think the previous speaker talked about the difficulty of trying to collect and interpret serious injury data, and for that reason he and many others of course focus their analysis on on fatal crashes.
However, serious injuries account for about 15 times the amount of crashes that fatales do.
And indeed, if you look at it as a burden of injury, serious injury is far more costly to our community than fatales.
I just wanted to make that point becausw what we tried to do in this study.

The Enhanced Crash Investigation study was to really look at how we could use serious injury data to tell us a bit more about the cause of crashes because we would suspect that serious injury crashes or the causes of women likely to be quite different too.
Photos.
OK, so by way of background, the Accident Research centre or markers we tend to be called have been collecting in depth crash data.
Now for a number of years.
In fact, for 20 years this year.
Now we've used these data for a number of what we'd call secondary safety analysis, such as identifying crash and injury problems that occur to vehicle occupants.
Using those data, we've been able to help our federal government in justifying the need for further vehicle safety regulations.
We've also conducted various cost benefit analysis using those data.
And also the auto industry, particularly the local auto industry in Australia, is very interested in using these data as a means for trying to identify how they can further improve their vehicles.

But we thought we'd try something a little different, and as far as I'm aware, this is probably a very novel approach to the use of in depth data, and that was really to try and help Rd safety professional stakeholders identify some new and innovative safety initiatives.
I'll take you through that process.
So the objectives we set out with the study were to gain a more comprehensive account of factors involved in serious injury, Rd crashes.
And then to use this information.
To try and innocence, train some of the people working.
Some of the professionals working in Rd safety to come up with innovative approaches to their work using a safe system model and I'll talk a bit more about that in a moment.
Um in Victoria, the state that I come from in Australia.
We have a Rd safety strategy like most other States and countries, not just Australia but around the world.
Looking at what sort of level of of injury reduction they should be aiming for over the next.
Two years in, Victoria is called arrive alive and and our government was very interested to see whether or not this approach might actually help them address some of the targets that they've set.
We tend to operate in our country in at least in our center, using what we call a safe system approach.
It it's a variation of vision 0, but one that seems to be more tolerant to our governments to our politicians, particularly.
There's a number of principles behind a safe system approach.
The first one is that crashes are going to continue to occur in spite of our best efforts to try and prevent them.
Purely becausw humans continue to make errors, and in in best world we would like humans not to.
But humans are humans.
However, given that they make errors, we have a principle that they shouldn't be killed or seriously injured as a result of that.
In other words, the system should be safe enough to tolerate indiscretions when they happen to drivers, and it really does all revolve around this notion of what's an acceptable tolerance.
At what stage will the body be able to resist serious, serious trauma?
Now the safe system involves a number of elements, safer vehicles, safer roads, safer drivers, but also safer speeds.
And I guess we were just starting to touch on the issue of safer speeds in the last discussion, and that's something that we think is absolutely critical in terms of future improvements in Rd safety.
I will.
I won't say anymore about that in this presentation though.
So the safe system approach does try to manage crash energy.
That's what it's all about in such a way that we can minimize trauma.
Now it's not taking away the responsibility of drivers to drive safely, but it is saying that the whole Rd safety approach ought to focus far beyond just the driver.
Yes, drivers must drive or behave in a responsible way, but the system also should be responsive.
Well enough to address their indiscretions when they happen.
So how do we go about the study we collected in depth data and this is predominantly involving serious injury cases?
Non fatal cases that occurred right across the state of Victoria was relatively representative, but again, this is a relatively small study, so we don't make any claims about its representativeness.
At this stage.
Oops, sorry, now I don't know if I can go back.
Can you take me back the slide, please?
Thank you.
Having been collected those cases, we took them back to the areas where they actually occurred and we pulled together what we called a panel of experts.
People whose responsibility it is for Rd safety in those areas like design engineers and medical people, emergency service people, and so on.
And we took them through those cases as a means of demonstrating to them the factors involved in those pressures, and we encourage them to think of it more broadly.
Think of it within this concept of a safe system approach.
And then we also monitored what the outcome of the study is, and there were some really interesting practices.
I guess that came out of the study that.
Will talk about.
So the in depth approach that we use is not dissimilar to other countries that collect in depth data because it's basically patient driven.
We start the case off when somebody is hospitalized from the crash.
And that's our definition of serious injury.
Crash as it is in most countries.
I guess having done that, we then track down with the vehicles are and do a fairly in depth investigation of the vehicle.
Looking at the usual factors of intrusion, distortion, crash severity and so on.
We also establish injury severity from the patients medical records.
And then finally we we go back and visit the site.
So this is a retrospective examination that's not on on the spot.
We'd love to do that, but nobody seems to want to pay us to do that.

However, if you get back to the site within as we tried to understudy within a week, there's usually sufficient evidence there that's available to confirm some of the stories that we get in the course of putting together the case, and we collect the police report we collect the ambulance reports.
We asked the people themselves and any witness statements that we've got as well.
So we've we've got a fair amount of data.
How reliable it is.
I can talk about that.
Or if you wish.
So this is the process that we set up was actually set up by a state government.
We collected the cases and we made our first judgment about what we thought the factors associated with the case.
We're not looking here at primary factor.
We're looking at all of the factors that were associated.
At least the ones that we could identify.
We then took those cases back to the regions we had this panel discussion.
They were able to identify other factors if they could be justified at the end of the process, they had to confirm that our findings were relevant.
Some of the findings occurred across regions, so they were more a statewide issue, and for that we took them back to a higher level regional central panel.
Who then took on responsibility for addressing those issues?
They tended to be the more costly issues, of course.
So let me just take you through one case which isn't going to present.
This this is a head on crash that occurred on a bend in a rural area in Victoria, the although you didn't see it, the blue car was traveling from the bottom to the top.
In Australia.
We drive on the other side of the road to Europe.
Red car was traveling along.
The blue car was attempting to get up to I'll show you on the next line.
Tempting to turn off.
That was a very crude model that we did have the case just to demonstrate.
Um?
You need to.
I'm back again, sorry.
Here's the crash, not the next one.
So here's the description of the crash.
This was on the two Lane, relatively narrow, undivided rural Rd in in the state that occurred right about mid well midday bit after midday in September the weather was dry.
It was clear there were light winds, but nothing unusual.
The case vehicle was a large Australian made passenger car driven by a 42 year old male.

His wife and two year old child were in the rear seat and unbeknown to them, a car coming in the other direction cut right across in front of them, therefore causing the crash 100 kilometer an hour speed zone.
On this road.
So the vehicle is traveling on the blue line up here and the yellow line represents the track of the car in the opposite direction, which is actually trying to get up a gravel Rd.
You can just start to see the track on the left hand side.
We're not sure why, because unfortunately, the driver of the other vehicle refused.
To participate, I guess because he got charged by the police, that might have actually caused him not to want to say anything.
That's the case vehicle.
It's about 1700 kilogram V.
So what we call a family sedan and you can see it's taken most of the impact on the front corner, which happens to be where the driver is the drivers there, the steering wheels just there.
That's the interior of the vehicle.
You can see it survived the crash reasonably well.
Little bit of damaged inside, but the amount of intrusion was not all that great.
Both the airbags were deployed.
That's the vehicle that cut across in front.
You can see that it's not survived as well.
It's an older vehicle, but also it's a much larger vehicle, about 900 kilogram.
And one of the.
Things we we hate to see is when that the roof rail above the door actually bends as it did in this one and again looking at inside enormous amounts of intrusion.
The driver survived, but as I say did not want to participate in our study.

So it's the police report that the non case vehicle vehicle one cut across turnball, turning into into captions Rd cut over double lines, which of course was not legal and struck the the case vehicle.
Which was traveling in that case vertically.
We collect the drivers description.
It was much more complicated than that.
Much more involved.
We spend about 3/4 of an hour with each of the people going over a whole range of issues.
We then look to confirm some of those descriptions.
One of the reports was that the driver actually left the road surface trying to avoid the oncoming vehicle.
And that was one of the issues that came out of the crash becausw the area.
The Verge area on the road was very poorly made.
Sign.
Now if taking you through most of those details, I think impact severity was very high for the small vehicle.
Again, that's mass difference.
I'm not quite sure that the 35 kilometers is all that real.
Unfortunately we are at the hands of the software that makes these calculations.
An and there was fairly minimal.
Well, there was some intra crush on the case vehicle, but.
Much more on the non case vehicle.
They are the injuries that suffered to the driver.
Very minor, some bruising on the chest essentially caused by probably seat belt loading and some lacerations to both left and right hand.
Nothing there of any consequence.
The driver was not actually hospitalized, but the passenger was, which is what drove the case.
She suffered fairly major injuries.
Remember she was in the back seat of the car, not the front.
Master Bruce fractured four ribs bruising to the spleen and lacerations to a kidney and ISS of 25 is starting to get quite serious.
Most of those injuries we attributed to the poor alignment of the seat belt around.
Torso.
There's the vehicles that were fairly roadworthy.
The case vehicle rated significantly better than every.
Choosing a used car safety rating system the non vehicle the Noncase vehicle was only fairly average and most of the restraint details are there which indicated that.
Both of those two occupants, and indeed the child, while restrained.
The crash site and I'll in the interest of time skip through some of these.
I think I probably mentioned most of those.
It was a fairly tight right hand curve in the direction of the case vehicle.
The shoulders were two to three meters wide.
Very poor drop offs.
There was a drop of about 100 millimeters between the seal and the verge, which was essentially a gravel verge, fairly low volume road and predominantly used by commr.
Vehicles and a few tourists.
As as these people were, so there's the crash site and this is taken as you as they as the case vehicle would have seen at approaching the crash site.
There's the view for the non case vehicle.
You can see in both cases there's not a lot of sight distance available, so they may not have even been aware until the last moment.
You can see the state of the edge of the road there.
Not.
Terribly good.
There's the crash site.

And struck the case vehicle coming in this direction.

So then we try and identify what were the factors and these are the ones that I guess from collecting the evidence we came up with in terms of the road, and we had a particular interest in in the infrastructure and the road surface itself.
The speed zone we felt may have been inappropriate for that road 100 kilometres an hour with such minimum scientists is not not particularly desirable.
It does lead to higher likelihoods of injury severity.
And in some cases crash.
You can see from their previous slide that we had poor Rd surfacing and an edging and there was practically no delineation at all.
And the restricted sight distance for which normally there would be at least advisory Chevron signs they were nonexistent.
In fact, there wasn't even an advisory sign at the time.
Vehicle the case vehicle seems to be OK. We contribute very much to that apart from perhaps the alignment of the seatbelts in the rear.
Becausw whether or not she was not necessarily in the right position.
Nevertheless, seatbelts in the rear in some of our cars really don't take account of biomechanics.
The only one that we could attribute for the noncase vehicle was its poor crashworthiness, but we weren't allowed to touch it anyway, apart from just take a few photos.

We couldn't identify any fault on the part of the case driver, but certainly for the non case driver failure to observe traffic control and the last statement is what he was charged with by the police driving without due care and attention.
Again, one of those very nebulous def.
Nations that police tend to use.
Now after we collect each of these cases, we go back to these panels to these regions again.
In fact, we went back three or four times to the country ones.

So it gives us a chance to go back and have a look at the site and see exactly whether or not anything is being done, because at the end of the process we actually assign some duties for for the people responsible to attend to.
I didn't bother showing your slider that, but in this case obviously one of the action items would have been to have done something about the site and to our pleasure we can see that they have.
There certainly addressed the problem with the edge of the road.
Now this is in the case vehicle direction.
They've obviously installed assign, which we would have liked to have seen a row of science Chevron signs along here to even further alert the motorist to this.
The sharpness of the bend, but.
That was perhaps expecting too much.

This happened within 2 two to three months of the original investigation an you can see in the other direction again they've improved the seal they've put in delineation lines and they've tried where they could to address some of that drop off problem that had been identif.
So overall we looked at 27 panel meetings involving about 80 crashes.
Some of them were in the Metro area summer in rural regions of the crashes we looked at about almost a little less than half were run off.
The road crashes, single vehicle crashes in many cases, some involved intersections somewhere a range of other types, including this one, which would have been classified as ahead on.
We identified 225 separate Rd safety issues and those crashes, of which 40% of them were pleased to admit were actually attended to between meetings.
Some of the key factors identified, obviously Rd infrastructure and speeding we we noted inappropriate speed limits in many of these sites, particularly given the nature of the roads involved.
Some of the roadside settings rigid objects close to the edge of the road, in this case narrow surface our normal Lane in Australia is 3.7 meters.
These were three meters, so they're relatively narrow.
Lack of runoff protection, such as barriers on any of our, some of the best roads in our country.
The most scenic roads are also the most hazardous.
Road geometry was a problem.
Intersections were problem.
We saw a number of motorcycle crashes are in our studies.
And an occupant extraction was an issue for some of the emergencies.
This people.
Some of the other issues that came out that I guess we would not have been aware of any other way.
The high use of prescription drugs.
We found a number of people involved in the crashes were on antidepressants.

We found a noted a high level of fatigue in many of the urban and rural crashers Conspicuity seeing motorcycles seem to be an issue in the motorcycle pressures, not not necessarily by them, of course, but by other vehicles.
Effective barrier design for urban environments and they're currently involved in a program improving barrier barrier protection in rural areas, but it's also a problem in urban areas.
And some development of low-cost treatments that curves on minor roads we felt may well be useful, particularly in that case I just saw you.
Anne Anne how do you address this low volume Rd maintenance problem?
On the verge?
I'm not sure we've been able to do it here, but it's more of a black spot.
Statement on a statewide treatment which we like to see.
And just to finalize, we asked the respondents what they thought of this process, thinking that they may well have been totally offended by it all.
But in fact they said no, they thought this was good.
It gave them greater insights, things that they were not normally think about in their day to day activities.
I felt that it was beneficial.
I guess the responsiveness that we found was certainly indicative of their keenness.

To be to be involved in the study, we asked their organizations what they thought about it and they were pleased and noted that in fact 40% of the treatments had actually been implemented as a result of the study.
Um, 60% felt that their involvement led to them adopting more of a strategic approach to their day to day activities, and I guess that was one of the objectives we tried.
Achieve.
So in conclusion, we felt that it's been relatively successful in achieving its objectives.

At this stage, we've only collected 80 cases, which you can't do very much about in terms of statistics, but I'm pleased to say that our state governments just awarded us another five years of funding for this study to continue, and we would hope that at the end of it all, we would be able to come up with some fairly robust findings from the study.
The program has led to significant benefits already.
Particularly more in a black spot treatment way, but some of the improvements are statewide.

It certainly highlighted awareness of the approach in the regions, and some of them still tell us even though we're not currently working in the areas we're about to start again, that they still try and adopt that sort of an approach, and I guess the positive feedback.
Obviously, from those who participated is also a measure of its part, me.
It's likely ongoing success.
So thank you very much.
You want more details to send me an email?
Thank you Brian.
I'm sure there are other questions on this presentation.
Yes.
Sharma my name is John.
Questions you could also do the first presented.
Did you use or do you have access to the data speed and discoloration data from the airbag mortgage?
Yeah, yeah, that's that's a really interesting question and and indeed we just.
Managed to gain approval by one of our local manufacturers to actually download the module.
We've always had great concern in estimating what the crash severity is because I guess for the most of the programs, we don't know what these stiffness values are of the cars.
Generally, in our fleet we have to rely on in many cases American stiffness values.
We've tried to correct as much as we can, but at the end of the day there.
We recognize as a fairly large tolerance, and indeed some of the results we often get just don't make sense to us, and it really depends on the on the nature of the crash itself.
If it happens to be in a very soft region of the car, such as a narrow offset collision, these programs are just not reliable at all.
So yeah, we would love to get access to the module data.
As I say, the first step we've got one manufacturer now to agree to us using it.
On the very restrictive conditions, I must say because of the legal implications of the data and and the likelihood of it being being used in a in a criminal or or a traffic claim.
But but we're pleased for that and hopefully will be able to get others to to go along as well.
I think in some cases.
The initial resistance that we had to asking for that sort of data is tending to diminish because they realize that it can be both a negative and a positive for them.
We we don't try and stress and negative.
We leave that to the lawyers but but the positiveness is something that hopefully will will make them realize that it's useful.

Maybe a little bit more realistic estimation.

Yeah.

The speed limit was hundreds kilometers per hour, so this is quite high for a Rd.
Yeah, well maybe this one under any general guidelines for this industry?
Well yeah the guidelines say 100 kilometers an hour.
That to me, it's absolutely bizarre.
The speeds that we put on some of our roads, in fact in another study I'm doing, we've actually compared our roads.
Our speed limits in Australia to speed limits here in Europe and speed limits in the US and.
Certainly in terms of urban speeds and these sorts of roads, we are probably about as high as anything around the world.
We've been trying to embark on a program to get our governments to actually seriously look at bringing the speed limits down on some of these roads.
There's a couple of instances now where it's happened where 100 kilometer an hour roads that clearly should not be 100 kilometers an hour.
Very windy roads often running through.
My wrist.
They've been able to bring down to 80, but there's such a public reaction such a public outcry are to wanting to reduce speeds that you know they only tend to do it in piece meal fashion.

Perhaps with enough evidence that even these small trials can lead to Rd safety benefits, we may well be able to convince them that that they seriously need to do something about speed limits in our country.

They immediately revert to the guidelines, but the but the guidelines say, I mean one example we had were minor roads running into major roads where vehicles, for whatever reason would just enter the major Rd without stopping or without any awareness of the volume of traffic running on those roads.

So overall we looked at 27 panel meetings involving about 80 crashes.
Some of them were in the Metro area summer in rural regions of the crashes we looked at about almost a little less than half were run off.
The road crashes, single vehicle crashes in many cases, some involved intersections somewhere a range of other types, including this one, which would have been classified as ahead on.
We identified 225 separate Rd safety issues and those crashes, of which 40% of them were pleased to admit were actually attended to between meetings.
Some of the key factors identified, obviously Rd infrastructure and speeding we we noted inappropriate speed limits in many of these sites, particularly given the nature of the roads involved.
Some of the roadside settings rigid objects close to the edge of the road, in this case narrow surface our normal Lane in Australia is 3.7 meters.
These were three meters, so they're relatively narrow.
Lack of runoff protection, such as barriers on any of our, some of the best roads in our country.
The most scenic roads are also the most hazardous.
Road geometry was a problem.
Intersections were problem.
We saw a number of motorcycle crashes are in our studies.
And an occupant extraction was an issue for some of the emergencies.
This people.
Some of the other issues that came out that I guess we would not have been aware of any other way.
The high use of prescription drugs.
We found a number of people involved in the crashes were on antidepressants.

We found a noted a high level of fatigue in many of the urban and rural crashers Conspicuity seeing motorcycles seem to be an issue in the motorcycle pressures, not not necessarily by them, of course, but by other vehicles.
Effective barrier design for urban environments and they're currently involved in a program improving barrier barrier protection in rural areas, but it's also a problem in urban areas.

The program has led to significant benefits already.
Particularly more in a black spot treatment way, but some of the improvements are statewide.
